Huh, I wasn't expecting to be skeptical of this series, but there's a lot here that I don't buy! The broader points sound fine to me but the arguments are quite sketchy:  5:50 Wikipedia says twinkie defense is mostly myth: "Contrary to common belief, White's attorneys did not argue that the Twinkies were the cause of White's actions, but that their consumption was symptomatic of his underlying depression."  9:54 The reason "11 colors" is unimpressive isn't "categories", it the fact that using 11 colors is objectively easy in this economy! A more honest comparison would be "my painter friend can draw a thousand 5x7-inch rectangles in a minute"... not a category I'm familiar with, but it would still be kinda impressive!  12:00 The 4th shape seems objectively more information-dense. A more fair example would be a hyperbola, or perhaps 3 lines in this shape:  |_|   Are those also hard to recall? (Though, I imagine his point is correct, and could be illustrated easily by comparing a complicated shape like "cartoon of a panda bear" to a similarly complex shape like "oval with seven random shapes in it".)  16:15 Mot of this seems invalid when there's no requirement that students wait to start writing. The difficulty might come from being unable to write 5 numbers down within the quick burst of time they are given in. (Because even if everyone simply had 1 or 2 digits of short-term memory, the 5-digit bursts would still be hardest because you can't finish writing the digits as he is saying them.)  36:00 Wikipedia is skeptical, noting "Reviews in 2006 and 2013 concluded that menstrual synchrony likely does not exist." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_synchrony

@bedirhanozkan6376  It talks a lot about our (human) stress system... How animals (like zebras) have a surge of chemical changes that help them flee a threat to their life, but then... when the threat is over... their brain and bodies go back pretty quickly to homeostasis. In contrast, humans continue to dwell on/stress out about lots of different, stressful situations- whether they are actually life-threatening or not. It was assigned reading in a "Death and Grieving" class I took, for one of my "Theme" classes (required at Chico State. ;-)  BTW, if you're interested in what-was-MY-favorite part of the book, it was his observations and research on a troop of baboons! 6 minutes in, and I feel that there's a large error that should be corrected, re: the Twinkie Defense. The defense did not argue that blood sugar fluctuations caused murder, but that the perpetrator, a known health nut, ate a twinkie before the murder, showing that he was not in his rational state of mind, thus leading to an argument of Diminished Capacity. Argument of Diminished Capacity is not the same as an argument for lack of culpability, and this is a very important distinction.

The Welsley Effect has since been disproven. It is worth noting that the degradation of facts is a known phenomenon. I.E. take any given "fact" and add time and odds are new evidence will be unearthed that either outright disprove it or totally alters our understanding of it. E.g. Yes the Earth does orbit the Sun, but our Solar System isn't static.  The whole thing spirals along as the Sun itself moves along.

🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  00:00 🧑‍🏫 Introduction to the Course - Overview of a case involving unusual behavior. - Introduction of three possibilities for the behavior: deep creep, midlife crisis, or genetic mutation. - Setting the stage for exploring genetic influences on behavior. 03:17 🧬 Exploring Commonalities in Behavior - Four seemingly unrelated events with a commonality: having your period, having a brain tumor, eating junk food, and taking anabolic steroids. - Revealing the common factor: successful use in courts to explain a murderer's behavior. - Emphasis on the influence of body processes on brain function. 06:34 💔 Interconnectedness of Body and Mind - Illustration of how thoughts about the heart affect its beating rate. - Introduction of the course's first key concept: the influence of bodily processes on brain activity. - Emphasizing the bidirectional relationship between physiological states and mental processes. 08:02 🤔 Categorical Thinking Challenges - Discussing the inherent human tendency to think in categories. - Examples illustrating problems with categorical thinking, including underestimating similarities and overemphasizing differences. - Introduction of the challenge to avoid categorical thinking in understanding complex biological behaviors. 20:50 🔄 Resisting Categorical Thinking in Behavioral Analysis - Highlighting the dangers of explaining behavior solely within one category. - Using the example of why a chicken crosses the road to demonstrate different categorical perspectives. - Emphasizing the course's approach to resist categorical explanations and understand the interconnectedness of biological and behavioral aspects. 24:13 🧬 Biological Influences Overview - Human behavior is influenced by hormones and genes. - The discussion includes the role of genes, hormones, and evolution in shaping behavior. 25:35 🤔 Critique of Categorical Thinking - Critique of the oversimplification in categorical thinking within professional biology. - Examples include quotes from influential figures like John Watson and their limited perspectives on behavior. 28:01 🧠 Challenges in Understanding Human Behavior - Exploration of challenges in understanding human behavior from a biological perspective. - Discussion includes synaptic adjustments, the limitations of behaviorism, and the complexities of brain function. 32:43 🌐 Goal of Resisting Categorical Thinking - Emphasis on the goal of avoiding categorical thinking in understanding human behavior. - Acknowledgment of the diverse factors influencing behavior and the need to resist simplistic explanations. 33:11 🧑‍🔬 Three Intellectual Challenges in Behavioral Biology - Introduction to the three intellectual challenges in the study of human behavioral biology. - Challenges include recognizing our similarities with other animals, understanding unique uses of typical physiology, and exploring behaviors with no parallels in the animal kingdom. 41:11 📚 Course Structure and Strategy - Overview of the course structure, divided into the introduction of various biological buckets and the examination of specific behaviors. - Highlighting the pain of jumping between different buckets initially and the rewarding aspect of putting all the pieces together in the second half of the course. 45:01 🎓 Course Logistics and Importance - Addressing logistics, such as weekly sections, midterm, and final, emphasizing no prerequisites for the course. - Stressing the importance of learning behavioral biology for informed decision-making in various aspects of life. 46:29 📚 Course Books and Reading Assignments - Two assigned books for the course, one authored by the speaker. - "Chaos" by James Gleick is the second book, with varying opinions among students. - Emphasis on a different way of thinking about biology, moving away from reductionism. 47:50 🌀 Chaos and Complexity in Biology - Traditional reductionist model vs. Chaos theory. - Understanding complex behaviors vs. fixing clocks. - Introduction to Chaos as a field and its impact on thinking about biology. 49:18 📖 Course Readings and Online Resources - Transition from traditional readers to online resources. - Variety in reading assignments, including whole papers, abstracts, and problem-solving approaches. - Emphasis on accessing information online, reducing paper usage. 50:45 📑 Online Coursework and Logistics - Abundance of online resources, including handouts, lecture notes, and Q&A. - Avoiding excessive paper usage by posting materials on Coursework. - Logistics, announcements, and changes will be communicated through online platforms. 51:42 🗓️ Course Schedule and Sections - Start of regular sections and office hours. - Midterm schedule and its purpose for review. - Considerations for managing the flow of people in and out of the lecture hall. 52:39 🧑‍🏫 Teaching Assistants and Section Options - Summary :   1. Hormones and body conditions affect brain functioning.  Hormones and body conditions can have a significant impact on brain functioning, leading to abnormal behavior. These factors can be used in legal cases, with the Twinkie defense being an example. Understanding the relationship between thoughts, emotions, memories, and physiology is crucial in grasping complex social behavior.  2. Categorization simplifies understanding yet can oversimplify.  Categorization helps us understand complex things by simplifying them, but it can also lead to oversimplification and difficulty differentiating between similar things. Language plays a major role in how we perceive and categorize objects, as shown by studies on color and shape recognition. Different languages draw boundaries at different points, affecting our ability to remember words.  3. Interplay of biology and behavior is highly complex.  The video highlights the complex interplay between hormones, genes, fetal development, and evolutionary pressures in influencing behavior. A key takeaway is to avoid categorical thinking and analyze the interactions between neurons, circuitry, and sensory stimulation. This approach helps understand behavior in various contexts.  4. Behaviorism's limitations in explaining human behavior.  The failure of behaviorism to fully explain human behavior is highlighted, discussing the scandal that led John Watson out of academia. The importance of brain synapses for normal psychic life is emphasized, and extreme treatments like electric shock therapy and frontal lobotomies are explored, including their dark history.  5. Importance of multiple influences on human behavior.  It's important to critically think about human behavior, considering various influences such as genes, hormones, neurons, and environment. Three intellectual choices when approaching the biology of human social behavior are mentioned, along with Conrad Lorenz's discovery of imprinting in birds.  6. Menstrual synchronization in hamsters and humans.  Female hamsters can synchronize their ovulation cycles when housed together, and male hamsters can desynchronize and shorten the synchronization cycle of females. Similarly, women tend to synchronize their menstrual cycles with roommates during freshman year of college, likely due to olfactory cues. However, if a woman is in a close intimate relationship with a male, her cycle may desynchronize. The synchronization occurs between socially outgoing and dominating individuals.  7. Unique power of human physiology.  Humans possess a unique ability to use their physiology in remarkable ways, such as experiencing empathy and a wide range of emotions. This sets them apart from other animals and adds to the complexity of understanding human behavior.  For summarized notes of all the lectures, check here : https://www.wisdominanutshell.academy/tag/human-behavioral-biology-robert-sapolsky/

1. Sometimes what's happening in your body can affect what happens in your brain.  2. Sometimes what's going in your brain can influence what happens in your body.  3. The interconnections and interactions of physiology and behaviour. The study of biology of human social behaviour.   4. We approach categorically. And then label those categories. Which results in forming boundaries that shape our narratives. Resulting in  how we perceive and what we perceive and evaluate. Categories makes it easy to remember and evaluate. But their are limitations to categorical thinking:   a) You can't differentiate between two facts that fall in same category. (Underestimate the differences)  b) And cant see similiarities even if they fall in different categories.(Overestimate the differences)  c) When you pay too much attention to boundaries you don't see the big picture.  5. Taking one step at a time backwardly explaining behaviour. There is no bucket(explanations/theory/category) only temporary platforms that helps in understanding all the influences came beforehand at that point of time.  6. One can have explanations and know theories. And still be wrong. Resist the temptation to be in a single bucket(category) and describing all the influences.   7. Intellectual challenges:  a) We share many animalistic tendencies. There is nothing fancy about us.  b)We do something different with the similarities we share with other animals. The same boring physiology used in different ways.  c) We do something that no other animal does. The importance of objectively describing behavior and working backwards to understand the underlying neural and hormonal mechanisms. Tracing behavior back through development, genetics, and evolution to gain a complete understanding of it.  The speaker begins by engaging the audience and introducing the concept of thinking in categories. The speaker then introduces the goal of the class to understand how the body influences behavior, emotions, and memories without relying on categorical thinking. They highlight the importance of objectively describing behavior and working backwards to understand the underlying neural and hormonal mechanisms. We are thinking in language and decoding thoughts in terms of language. Our brains chunk knowledge delivered in language form to abstractions giving the illusion of awareness independent from language.
